page.title: 01Copinsay : East of Orkney
page.content: Copinsay is a wedge-shaped island with cliffs rising to 200ft in the east and sloping to sea level in the west. The rocks are mainly middle old red sandstone flags laid down in shallow fresh water, they are some 350 to 400 million years old. Copinsay, ungrazed for 10 years, is covered in rough grass. The island was purchased to be a nature reserve by friends of James Fisher, author and naturalist, who died in 1970, to his memory. Copinsay is a seabird colony of national importance with many types of birds, especially large colonies of kittiwakes and guillemots on the SE Cliffs. A lighthouse was build in 1914 and at present is manned by 6 men on a month on month off basis with 3 men on the island and 3 ashore. The lighthouse has been recently modernised.
